So one of the things that it's known to be able to do is help to bring the magnesium out of you know so if you have a a mine tailing waste and it's got magnesium in it often times the magnesium isn't necessarily reactive because it's bound in a silica structure and it's very difficult to get it out. But when you add oxalate or or oxalic acid to the solution it actually helps to dissolve the magnesium and make it reactive for crystallization and mineralization with CO2. And so one of the things like the Opus 12 was looking at is working with a company called Solidia and so very different but looking at Solidia's process I don't know if you guys know Solidia is a company where they make low carbon concrete ultimately. And so one process in which they do that instead of curing with water they cure with CO2. And it turns out that if you add oxalic acid in that process you enhance the uptake of CO2 through the curing process. And so really it's it's like you know that acid allows the magnesium atoms in your feedstock if it's a mineralization approach to be more reactive to CO2 and to help bind it but it's towards a permanent product not necessarily like like you wouldn't use it as a a fuel you would use it as a part of an enhancement process for mineralizing CO2. So that's how I see it

utterance: Julia Brown UK Climate Change Committee: I wonder who we haven't heard from for a little while. Sharma. What are your thoughts at the moment?

annotations.encourage participation: The speaker, Julia Brown, invites Shaama M. Sharada to share their thoughts, encouraging participation in the discussion.

utterance: Shaama M. Sharada: Sorry. Yeah. At least based on my understanding of the ways in which we can convert CO2, I know there's a huge push towards electrochemistry because there is that's one sustainable way of leveraging solar and wind to convert to electricity and then use that towards reducing CO2. One of the things that is kind of less explored at least based on my understanding is using light directly. So one of the things that you can achieve with light which is difficult to achieve in an electrochemical process is the one electron reduction of CO2. When you talk about electrochemistry you're talking about two or more electron reduction of CO2 right because one electron has a very very high over potential associated with it. So those kind of reductions can be achieved using photo redox chemistry. So essentially using light to drive a photo redox catalyst to become an anion and that anion can push one electron towards CO2. And as far as I understand it there are operational issues associated with it which is why as of right now it's mostly focused on highly specific applications. It could either be things like adding COOH groups to aromatics so basically carboxylate styrene and make a polymer precursor. Attach a carboxylic acid to an amine and make an amino acid which can go into pharmaceuticals. So there are a lot of specialized applications that we can think of. The challenge of course being making sure that these catalysts are cyclable and coming up with continuous processes. But at least there are lab scale continuous processes that exist now that leverage these light assisted pathways. So I think we can do more difficult chemistry as well beyond what is shown with electrocatalysis and we can think beyond formic acid right because you can use any kind of substrate and link a carboxylate group to it.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces using light directly for one electron reduction of CO2.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker elaborates on challenges and applications of photo redox chemistry for CO2 reduction.
annotations.encourage participation: The speaker encourages thinking beyond electrocatalysis and formic acid.

utterance: Julia Brown: Are there some exciting in particular exciting challenges that that we need some more research in in that area something that

annotations.ask question: The speaker is requesting information about challenges in the discussed area, seeking more research needs.

utterance: Shaama M. Sharada: Yeah so one of the issues that that I see with some of the catalysts that we look at is the cyclability. Because you're using light in addition to doing the photo redox chemistry these molecules tend to degrade rather rapidly. So you get five turnovers and everything dies out. And this is and the issues are I think kind of common between the materials used for catalysis and the materials we use for organic LEDs for example. So I think there is a lot of opportunity in trying to identify what those degradation pathways are and finding ways to mitigate them and that has applications across all kinds of light all kinds of photonic materials not just photo redox chemistry.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on the challenge of cyclability and material degradation in catalysts for photo redox chemistry.
